full_desc:
Color photographic print showing a theatrical performance on an outdoor stage, associated by reference with the “Lost Colony” drama on Roanoke Island, North Carolina. The image centers on an adult performer in elaborate period costume standing mid‑step on a set of broad stone-like stairs leading up to a large wooden throne. The stage floor in the foreground appears sandy or light tan, suggesting an outdoor amphitheater or beach-like setting.

The performer wears a brightly colored, ornate outfit resembling a Renaissance or Elizabethan jester or court figure. The costume includes a fitted doublet and short, flared skirt or tabs in red, green, and gold tones, heavily trimmed with decorative braids and patterns. A large, white, pleated ruff encircles the neck. The performer has dark leggings and pointed footwear. They hold a tall, thin staff or spear-like prop in one hand and a multicolored, flowing drape or pennant in the other, with visible panels of yellow, green, red, and purple fabric. The posture is dynamic, with one leg raised as if stepping down the stairs.

Behind the performer, the background is dominated by a set wall designed to resemble large, rough-cut stone blocks in shades of brown and gray. On the right side of the image, at the top of the steps, is an ornate wooden throne. The throne has a high, rectangular back with carved detailing at the top and rope-like vertical trim on either side. The backrest is upholstered in a light, tufted material with dark buttons arranged in a grid. The seat and base are plain wood, with armrests supported by vertical posts and a small platform beneath. The stairs leading up to the throne are surfaced in two textures: dark, stone-like treads and risers, and a central runner of bright red carpet decorated with repeating yellow and white geometric or diamond patterns.

On the left side of the image, another performer is partially visible, standing near the stone wall and stair. This individual is costumed in a voluminous, textured outfit covered with overlapping dark blue and green leaf-shaped pieces, creating the appearance of a dense foliage or shrub costume. Their form is mostly obscured by this leafy covering, and only the general silhouette is visible. No legible text appears anywhere in the scene. The overall condition of the photograph suggests mid-20th-century color film, with slightly muted tones and minor grain, but the image remains clear and well-preserved, capturing details of the costumes and stage set for archival and accessibility purposes.
safety_reason: No elevated risks identified.
alt_text: Color photograph of a “Lost Colony” outdoor stage performance on Roanoke Island, with a jester-like court figure in ornate Renaissance-style costume stepping down stone-like stairs toward a large wooden throne. A second performer in a dense blue-green foliage costume stands partially visible beside the stone wall.
alt_text_no_demo: A color photograph of a “Lost Colony” outdoor theatrical performance shows a costumed court jester–like performer mid-step on stone-like stairs leading to a large wooden throne. A second performer in a dense leafy costume stands partially visible near the stage wall.

full_desc:
Black-and-white photographic print showing an office interior, identified by the reference information as connected to the North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Company in Durham, North Carolina. The scene is composed of three Black adults in business attire working in a relatively small office furnished with dark wooden furniture. The viewpoint is from in front of a large wooden desk that dominates the right half of the image; the background wall runs horizontally across the scene, with a tall vertical structural element or window frame slightly right of center.

In the right foreground, a Black adult sits behind the large, paneled wooden desk. They wear a dark three-piece suit with a white shirt and a bow tie. Their body faces slightly toward the left, and one arm rests on the desk, holding what appears to be a pen over an open ledger or large book. Several large books or ledgers lie open and stacked on the desk surface, along with additional papers. In the middle of the desk, close to the back edge, sits a small potted plant or floral arrangement. The desk has simple, rectilinear design and appears solid and heavy.

To the left, nearer the back wall, two other Black adults are seated at a smaller work area. One person sits at a roll-top or pigeonhole-style desk or shelving unit filled with papers, boxes, and bound volumes; their body is angled toward the camera, with legs crossed and one hand resting low at their side. The second person sits in front of this unit at a separate chair, closer to the center of the image, turned in profile toward the right. This person appears to be working at a smaller writing surface or intermediate table; parts of a lamp or other dark object sit on this work surface. Both individuals wear dark suits characteristic of formal business dress, with high collars and ties. The office chairs have curved wooden arms and legs; the nearer chair’s legs and casters are visible against the patterned floor.

The floor has a small, repeating pattern that suggests carpet or a dense patterned rug; near the lower center edge of the photograph there is a light-colored round object on the floor, possibly a shallow bowl or waste container. The back wall is largely plain and light-colored. On the upper center of the wall hangs a printed calendar or office notice with a prominent heading and a grid of dates below. A tall, narrow vertical element slightly to the right of the center—possibly a window frame or wall column—runs from the floor out of the top of the frame, suggesting the desk at right is near a window or structural division. The overall condition of the print shows some grain and limited contrast typical of early 20th-century photography, but the furnishings, clothing, and many details remain clearly visible.

The image appears to document a professional workspace or insurance office interior, focusing on the employees at their desks and their businesslike environment: ledgers, paperwork, a calendar, and storage furniture all suggest record-keeping and office administration as the main activity. The photograph likely serves as a historical record of an African American–run business office in Durham, North Carolina, showing both the physical setting and the formal attire and posture of the staff.

full_desc:
The image is a scanned page of a handwritten letter on lined paper. The writing covers almost the entire sheet, with the primary text written horizontally in cursive and additional notes written vertically along the left margin. The ink appears dark (likely black or dark blue) and contrasts clearly with the light background of the paper. The handwriting is moderately large, slanted, and somewhat ornate, typical of mid‑20th‑century cursive, with certain words and letters written over or corrected.

To the right of this person is a small work table crowded with weaving supplies, including multiple cones or spools of thread or yarn, a basket, and miscellaneous tools. This person wears a light-colored apron over darker clothing, indicating a work or instructional role.

In the right foreground, a large floor loom occupies the front edge of the frame, its warp threads clearly visible running front to back, with heddles, beater, and other loom components prominently shown. In front of this loom, an adult in a dark suit with a light dress shirt and tie slightly bends forward, appearing to show or explain something to a younger person seated at the loom. The younger person has light hair styled in a short cut and wears a light-colored shirt or smock; they are turned slightly toward the suited adult, suggesting an instructional interaction. On the wall behind them, several skeins or hanks of yarn in different shades hang from pegs, as well as what appears to be another, more vertical-style loom or frame.

The overall scene documents a functional weaving classroom or workshop in active use, with multiple looms, yarns, and tools visible, and several people engaged in weaving or instruction. The image is a colorized print from an illustrated newspaper laid out on a vertical page. It contains two large horizontal panels of artwork one above the other, with printed captions and masthead text. The overall style is that of a mid‑19th‑century engraved illustration that has been hand‑tinted with muted greens, browns, grays, and blues.

At the very top is the publication header. Centered near the top edge is the title “THE ILLUSTRATED LONDON NEWS,” with a page number “64” at the upper left and a date at the upper right. Directly beneath the masthead, across the width of the page, is a line of smaller text stating the subject of the illustrations, referring to the last days of the Confederate government and to sketches by a special artist.

The upper half of the page contains the first illustration. It shows a busy scene of Confederate troops in rapid movement across open ground bordered by tall trees. Several covered wagons with white canvas tops and reddish ribs move from right to left, drawn by teams of horses. Around and ahead of the wagons, numerous uniformed soldiers ride horses at a gallop. Their uniforms are rendered in gray-blue tones with darker caps, suggesting Confederate cavalry, and most carry long guns or carbines. One figure on foot runs alongside in the left foreground. The ground is grassy with churned‑up light brown dirt indicating haste. Behind the figures is a dense stand of green trees forming a solid backdrop. Beneath this illustration, in the center of the page, is a printed caption in small capital letters describing the scene as a sudden alarm and stampede of the Confederates.

The lower half of the page features the second illustration, depicting a river crossing within a hilly, wooded landscape. The wide river occupies the lower third of this panel, shaded in dark gray‑blue with ripples. In the foreground, several mounted soldiers guide their horses into or out of the water; some horses are chest‑deep, and a few riders are shown mid‑stream. On the near bank to the right, more soldiers stand with horses and a covered wagon; one rearing horse is depicted with its front legs off the ground while its handler tries to control it. On the left side of the river, a large flatboat or ferry loaded with at least one covered wagon and numerous people is being poled or guided across toward the viewer. In the background on both the near and far banks are additional lines of soldiers, horses, and wagons moving along paths, all set against rolling green hills and clusters of tall trees. The sky above is shaded with gray clouds, giving a somber tone. A caption printed below this illustration identifies the scene as the Confederate train crossing the Pee Dee River in North Carolina and refers readers to another page for further information.

The page appears in good condition with even margins and no obvious tears or stains. The printing is clear, with fine engraved lines visible in the artwork and consistent coloring. The overall artifact is a historical newspaper illustration documenting Confederate military movements during the closing period of the American Civil War, as interpreted by a contemporary artist and published in a British illustrated news magazine.

The image is a printed historical map from a publication, showing the town of Washington, North Carolina, and its surroundings during a Civil War battle or siege. The map is drawn in black ink on a light tan background, with a decorative border line around the main map area. The style is schematic rather than to exact scale, with simplified topographic textures and many handwritten-style printed labels identifying roads, forts, batteries, natural features, and military positions.

At the center of the map is a square grid labeled “WASHINGTON,” representing the streets of the town as a neat checkerboard of blocks. Directly below the town grid runs a horizontal waterway labeled “TAR RIVER,” with another waterway labeled “PAMLICO RIVER” continuing to the right, separated only by a stretch of shoreline indicating their junction. Along the rivers, small drawings indicate “OBSTRUCTIONS,” a “BRIDGE” crossing the river below the town, and named points such as “ELLISONS PT.” to the left and “RODMANS PT.” to the lower right. Below the rivers, the bottom edge of the map shows wooded and swampy terrain, illustrated with repeated tree and brush symbols, labeled “WOODS,” “WOODS AND SWAMP,” and dotted with several “REBEL BATTERY” labels, as well as specific positions like “COTTON BATTERY,” “REBEL BATTERY” near “RODMANS PT.,” and “CASTLE ISLAND AND FORT.” A small boat-like shape labeled “POCKET GUN-BOAT” is near the bridge.

Above the town, the map depicts Union defensive works in an arc, rendered as thick black lines, angled trenches, and small block symbols, with annotations for regiments and forts. To the left of Washington, an area marked “BREASTWORK & DITCH” and “TRAVERSES 44th MASS.” runs diagonally. Near it are other labels such as “Co. B 27th Mass.”, “No. 1,” and “Co. B 27th Mass.” again closer to the river. To the upper center is “FORT WASHINGTON,” drawn as a small rectangular fort icon with jutting angles. Farther to the right along the defensive arc appear positions marked “No. 3 Co. F. 27th Mass,” “PORT,” “27th MASS. REGT,” and a larger work labeled “FORT LOMBARD I. Co. 44th MASS.” Near the right riverbank is another enclosure labeled “FORT HAMILTON,” with a note “UNUSED” near it.

The surrounding countryside is filled with descriptive land-use and terrain labels. To the upper left is a large expanse of closely packed tree symbols labeled “WOODS,” and below them an area labeled “CORNFIELD.” Diagonal roads cut across: one labeled “GREENVILLE ROAD” runs from the lower left toward the center; another labeled “JAMESVILLE ROAD” runs from the top right toward the town; and further right is “Plymouth Road.” Several irregularly dotted regions are labeled “SWAMP” or “MARSH,” showing wetland areas north and east of Washington. Near the upper portion, the label “CLASHED TIMBER” appears amid small stump-like symbols, and the words “REBEL BATTERY” and “REBEL BATTERIES” are printed near the top left-center and upper right, respectively, indicating Confederate positions facing the town’s defenses.

In the river areas and along the lower edge, additional fortifications and objects are indicated. Along the town’s riverfront, small rectangular works are labeled “FORT CESTE” and “No. 2 FORT PARROTT [partially legible],” with a circular feature labeled “HOSPITAL” just inland. Below the town, across the river, a narrow strip of land includes “OBSTRUCTIONS” marked in the water, the “BRIDGE,” and “CASTLE ISLAND AND FORT” near the center. Multiple “REBEL BATTERY” labels and the term “WOODS AND SWAMP” run along the lower margin with stylized trees filling the space. A directional arrow in the Pamlico River points to the right, indicating the river’s flow or seaward direction.

Near the top center of the map is a simple compass rose labeled with the cardinal directions “N,” “E,” “S,” and “W,” with a decorative arrow-like pointer. The entire composition is framed with a narrow border line, and beneath the image at the bottom is a printed caption line in small capitals, identifying the map as depicting Washington on the Tar River, North Carolina, the Rebel batteries, and national defenses during a siege in April, with credit to an individual from a particular regiment. A small handwritten number appears in the lower right margin. The physical condition appears good, with even tone and no major visible tears, suggesting a printed plate or reproduction on paper.

Overall, this artifact appears to be a mid‑19th‑century printed battle or campaign map from the Civil War era, produced for a publication. It combines cartographic symbols, labeled military positions, and descriptive terrain to record the disposition of Union and Confederate forces around Washington, N.C., emphasizing forts, regimental positions, batteries, roads, swamps, woods, rivers, and obstructions in and around the town during a specific siege.

The item is a black-and-white reproduction from a publication, mounted on a gray backing sheet. At the top left of the backing sheet, there is a small rectangular printed label with typed text identifying the subject as being from the Biltmore Estate and referring to Napoleon’s chessmen and table. Centered on the backing is a vertically oriented photograph bordered by a light margin. Beneath the image, printed in small capital letters on the lower margin, is a caption repeating that description of the chessmen and table.

The photograph shows an ornate interior scene focused on a small rectangular wooden chess table with slender, straight legs and a shallow drawer on the visible side. The table surface holds an arranged set of chess pieces that appear to be finely carved figurines, all light-colored in the monochrome image, lined up in their starting positions on a smooth tabletop; the grid of the chessboard is not clearly visible and may be inlaid or implied by the arrangement. The table stands on an intricately patterned rug with dense, repeating motifs. On either side of the table are two upholstered chairs or stools with turned legs; the upholstery appears worn or richly patterned, and nailhead trim is visible along the edge on the right-hand seat.

Behind the chess table is a tall, curved-back sofa or settee whose back is covered with a tapestry-like fabric depicting a landscape with trees. Rising above and behind this piece is a large wall tapestry or series of hangings filling the upper background. The tapestry shows multiple seated and standing human figures in draped garments, possibly in a historical or courtly scene, rendered with detailed folds and shading. The wall and furnishings create a layered, richly decorated setting, typical of a formal historic interior, with textiles, carved wood, and decorative details closely packed within the frame. No people are physically present in the room.

The physical artifact appears to be in good condition: the backing board is clean and flat, the printed photograph is clear with a full tonal range, and the labels and caption are sharply legible. The visual style, subject, and captioning suggest this is a documentary interior view of a furnished room at Biltmore Estate, specifically highlighting the chess table and chessmen associated with Napoleon as an art or historic object display.

full_desc:
The image is a full-page color illustration reproduction from Harper’s Weekly, arranged as a collage of multiple small scenes depicting Asheville, North Carolina, and nearby locations. The page has a cream background and is printed in muted color tones resembling hand-tinted engravings. At the very top center is the publication title “HARPER’S WEEKLY” in serif capital letters. Below this, nine separate rectangular and nearly-rectangular illustrations are arranged in three columns, each with a small printed caption in all-capital serif type beneath it. At the bottom center is a main title line and page figure number.

Across the top row are three landscape and architectural views. The upper left illustration shows two small human figures standing on a rocky outcrop overlooking a vast mountainous landscape partly obscured by clouds or fog. The figures appear to be adults in dark clothing and hats, seen from behind, looking toward rolling mist-covered hills. The caption below reads “LOOKING OFF FROM CAESAR’S HEAD.” The upper right illustration shows a broad, winding river flowing through a green, hilly valley with trees and fields on both banks and distant hills in the background. The scene is softly colored in greens, browns, and grays and is captioned “THE FRENCH BROAD, FROM RICHMOND HILL.” Centered between these two landscapes but slightly lower is a horizontal view of a low, wide bungalow-style house made of stone or wood with a shingled, hipped roof and a chimney. Mature trees rise behind the structure, and the caption states “THE BUNGALOW—MR. JOHN BEATTY’S RESIDENCE.”

In the middle section are four illustrations showing people, buildings, and work. On the left, a small vertical scene shows a rustic log cabin built from rough timbers, with a simple pitched roof in a wooded setting. In front of the cabin stand two older Black adults (one wearing a light-colored long garment and apron, the other in darker clothing), facing outward toward the viewer. The caption below this scene is “OLD FOLKS AT HOME.” To the right of this is a larger rectangular illustration of a group of white adults on horseback gathered in front of a large stone and brick building with an arched entrance and steps. Several horses and riders are in the foreground, along with dogs lying or standing near them, suggesting a hunting party. Most of the adults wear riding clothes and broad-brimmed hats. The caption under this image reads “RETURN FROM A DEER-HUNT.”

Below these, on the left of the page, is a wide illustration labeled “A CHAIN-GANG.” It shows a group of incarcerated Black adults wearing striped uniforms working beside a rough dirt roadway cut into a hillside. They are overseen by white guards in civilian clothing and hats. Some of the prisoners appear to be using tools or moving earth; others stand in a line along the road. A wooden rail cart loaded with timber sits on tracks in the foreground near one of the uniformed prisoners. The background includes a sloping hillside, sparse trees, and distant water or valley. On the right, roughly aligned with this chain-gang scene, is a view of a large, multi-story hotel building with complex rooflines, gables, and turrets, constructed in a mix of stone and timber framing. A curving driveway or path leads up to the entrance, and small human figures stand or walk near the front. The caption reads “KENILWORTH INN, BILTMORE, TWO MILES FROM ASHEVILLE.”

The bottom row features two natural subjects and a panoramic landscape. At the lower left is a close-up botanical illustration of a rhododendron cluster, showing pale pink or white flowers and green leaves against a soft background. The caption “RHODODENDRONS” appears beneath it. To its right is a large panoramic view of mountainous terrain with multiple railroad tracks and tunnels. The scene shows steep green mountains, narrow valleys, and a sinuous railway line with visible trains and smoke plumes at numerous points as it winds through the landscape. The caption under this panel states “ROUND KNOB, SHOWING RAILWAY AT SEVENTEEN DIFFERENT POINTS.”

Centered under all the images at the bottom of the page is a line of text in all caps identifying the series: “ASHEVILLE, NORTH CAROLINA, AND ITS SURROUNDINGS.—[See Page 1288.]” A small four-digit number “1296” is printed directly below, likely a page or figure reference. The page appears clean and intact, with minor edge discoloration typical of aged paper but no major stains or tears visible. Overall, the artifact is a late-19th- or early-20th-century magazine illustration page documenting scenic, residential, and social views of Asheville and its environment, including leisure activities such as hunting, luxury accommodations, regional flora, transportation infrastructure, and a chain gang of Black prisoners under guard, reflecting both natural beauty and carceral labor in the region.

The image is a scanned page from an older printed publication, likely a 19th‑century book or magazine, titled at the top center “OF WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA.” The page number “535” appears in the upper right corner. The page is vertically oriented and shows both an illustration and columns of text printed in a serif typeface. The paper has a slightly yellowed tone consistent with age, with faint shadows and light edge wear visible along the margins.

In the upper left half of the page there is a black‑and‑white line illustration. It depicts a domestic service scene in an interior setting. A white adult is seated in a simple metal or wooden chair at a small round table covered with a cloth. This person wears a long, light‑colored dress with a high collar and long sleeves, and a fur or plush stole or collar around the shoulders. One arm rests on the table near a teacup and saucer, and there is a small teapot or similar vessel on the table. The seated individual’s posture is upright, facing left, suggesting they are a guest or patron, possibly at a hotel tea service.

Standing directly behind the seated person is a Black adult who appears to be a domestic worker. They wear a long, plain, light‑colored dress or uniform with long sleeves and a high collar, and dark shoes. They hold a large feather duster or fan made of long plumes in one hand, extended above the seated person’s head in a fanning gesture. The standing person’s other arm hangs by their side. Both figures are rendered in a detailed engraving or pen‑and‑ink style, with shading to indicate folds in the clothing and shadows on the floor. The background behind them is mostly plain, with some shading to suggest a wall or neutral backdrop. Beneath the illustration is a printed caption in small capital letters identifying the scene as “THE GUARDIAN ANGEL—EAGLE HOTEL, ASHEVILLE.” An artist’s signature appears just below and to the right of the standing figure.

Below the illustration and caption, the lower portion of the page is filled with two justified columns of printed text. The left column begins directly under the illustration and continues nearly to the bottom margin, with a narrow gutter separating it from the right column. The right column begins near the top right of the page beside the illustration and extends downward. The text describes scenic views, mountain peaks, and travel experiences in western North Carolina, including references to Whiteside Mountain, nearby ranges, specific peaks and locations, and an adventurous and dangerous mountain pass. The typography is uniform and clearly legible, with paragraph breaks indicated by indentations. There are no visible annotations, handwriting, or additional symbols on the page.

Overall, the artifact appears to be a single page from a travel or regional description volume about western North Carolina, combining narrative text with an illustrative vignette depicting service at the Eagle Hotel in Asheville. The physical condition seems good, with minimal damage, consistent inking, and clear printing, making both the illustration and the text easily readable for archival and accessibility purposes.
transcript:
OF WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA.                                                                      535

[under illustration]
THE GUARDIAN ANGEL—EAGLE HOTEL, ASHEVILLE.

But the outlook! It was the culmina-
tion—the finishing stroke of all our rich
and varied mountain surprises! When we
were seated on the white crag, over which
a fresh breeze perpetually blew, the
wrinkled world beneath us literally
"crawled." Everything seemed dwarfed
and insignificant below. Even the
brother crags—to the southwest, Fodder-
stack and Black Rock, and Stooly, to the
northwest—although in reality rising nearly
to the elevation of Whiteside, seemed like
small hills. To the northeast, as far as
the eye could reach, rose a multitude of
sharply defined blue and purple peaks, the
valleys between them narrow and filled with
frightful ravines, seeming the merest
gullies on the earth's surface. Farther
off than this line of peaks rose the dim out-
lines of the Balsam and Smoky Ranges.
In the distant southwest, looking across
into Georgia, we could descry "Yonah,"
lonely and superb, with a cloud
wreath about his brow; sixty miles away,
in South Carolina, a flash of sunlight
revealed the roofs of the little German set-
tlement of "Walhalla"; and on the south-

east, beyond the precipices and
ragged projections, towered up "Chimney Top Mou-
tain," while the "Hog Back"
bent its ugly form against the
sky, and "Cold Mountain"
rose on the left. Turning to
the north, we beheld "Yellow
Mountain," with its square
sides, and "Short-Off." Be-
yond and beyond, peaks and
peaks and ravines and ravines!
It was like looking down on
the world from a balloon.

The wealthy citizens of
South Carolina have long
known of the charms of this
section, and many of them
annually visit it. In a few
years its wildness will be tamed:
a summer hotel will doubtless
stand on the site of "Wright's"
farm-house, and the lovely
forests will be penetrated by
carriage roads; steps will be
cut along the ribs of Whiteside;
and a shelter will be erected
on its very summit. A storm
on the vast rock, with the light-
ning playing hide-and-seek in
the crevices of the precipice,
is an experience which gives
one an enlarged idea of the powers of
Heaven.

There is one pass on Whiteside which,
though eminently dangerous, is now and
then essayed, and Jonas, and one of the
woodsmen of our party, resolved to try it.
While we commoner mortals drank in the
wonderful view, and hob-nobbed with the
clouds, these adventurers clambered down
the precipice's sides, and coming to a point
not far from the Devil's Court-House, where
the pass begins, launched themselves boldly
forward. To gain a cave which is suppos-
ed in former times to have been the abode
of an Indian sorcerer or medicine-man, they
were compelled to step out upon a narrow
ledge running along the very side of the
cliff, and turning a corner with no support
above or below. The ledge or path is, at its
beginning, two feet wide, and, as it nears
the cavern, not more than eighteen inches
in width. A single misstep, or a failing of
the nerves would have precipitated them
some hundreds of feet into the valley, and above
them the comfortless rock rose three hun-
dred feet. Hugging the wall, and fairly
flattening themselves against it, they

full_desc:
The image shows an aged, yellowed newspaper or magazine clipping with three vertical columns of small printed text in a serif typeface. The paper appears thin and slightly worn, with darkened edges, minor creases, and some small tears, especially along the right margin where a tiny round hole and a rough edge are visible. The top edge looks a bit uneven, as if cut or torn from a larger page.

The left and center columns contain part of a prose story titled “The Stolen Apple.” The title is centered at the top of the left column in slightly larger bold type. Below it, the story is laid out in justified paragraphs. The narrative is written in the first person and describes a married person with three daughters, a modest but contented household, and a habit of bringing home small treats such as fruit or confectionery. The story describes purchasing fine apples, storing the remaining apples, and then a later conversation at the dining table when the spouse remarks that “father has found the way to my safety-box.” Further down, the text transitions into a dialogue scene printed in quotation marks. The middle column begins with a short quoted answer, followed by discussion of a suspected falsehood about an apple and a detailed dialogue between the narrator and their daughter Mary about whether she went into the garret with an apple and what she saw on the floor. In the course of that explanation, the story refers to a servant girl and mentions “the negro” in relation to blame for the missing apple. The printed text in these two columns is clearly legible, but the last line or two at the far right edge of the middle column are cut off where the clipping ends, so the final word or phrase is not fully present.

The right column presents a separate piece with its own heading: “Missionary Pennies.” This heading is also in slightly larger bold type and centered. Immediately below the heading is a brief description in smaller italics stating that it is a dialogue for two boys and one girl. The rest of the column is a poetic dialogue with character names in small capital letters (CHARLIE, JOHNNY, CARRIE) followed by short stanzas. transcript:
The Stolen Apple.

I had been married fifteen years. Three
beautiful daughters enlivened the domestic
hearth, the youngest of whom was in her
eighth year. A more happy and contented
household was nowhere to be found. My
wife was amiable, intelligent, and very con-
tented. We were not wealthy, but Provi-
dence had preserved us from want, and we
had learned "that contentment without
wealth is better than wealth without con-
tentment."

It was my custom, when returning home
at night, to drop into one of the many shops
that are constantly opened in the business
streets of the metropolis, and purchase some
trifling dainties, such as fruit or confec-
tionery, to present to mother and the chil-
dren. I need not say how delighted the
little ones were at this expression of paternal
consideration. On one occasion I had pur-
chased some remarkably fine apples. After
the repast, half a dozen were left untouched,
and my thrifty companion forthwith re-
moved them to the place of deposit, where
it was her custom to preserve the remains of
our nicknacks. A day or two after, when
I had seated myself at the table to dine, she
said to me, smiling, "So father has found
the way to my safety-box, has he?"

I was at a loss to understand the meaning,
and desired her to explain.

"Have you not been to my drawer?"

"No, sa."

Now, it was evident that falsehood existed
somewhere. Could it be that one of my
children had told me a lie! The thought
harassed me. I was not able to attend to
business. I went to the store, but soon
returned again. Meanwhile the servant-
girl had communicated to her mistress that
she had seen our youngest go into the garret
with a large apple, the morning before.
On examination, the core and several pieces
of the rind were found upon the floor. I
again called Mary to me, and said to her
affectionately,

"Mary, my daughter, did you not go
into the garret yesterday?"

"Yes, sir."

"Did you go there with an apple?"

"No, sir."

"Did you notice any thing on the floor?"

"No, sir."

I was unwilling to believe my sweet child
capable of telling me a falsehood, but ap-
pearances seemed against her. The fault
lay between her and the servant, and, while
I was desirous to acquit my child, I did not
wish to accuse unjustly the negro. I
therefore, took Mary into a room alone.
I spoke to her of the enormity of lying; of
the necessity of telling the truth; of the
severe penalty I should be compelled to
inflict upon her if she did not confess the
whole [partially legible]

Missionary Pennies.

A dialogue for two boys and one girl.

CHARLIE.

See here! see here! a bright new cent
My father gave to me;
O Johnny, say, what would you buy
With it if you were me?

JOHNNY.

I've got a penny, too; see here!
And though it is quite small,
I'll buy some candy, I am sure,
Or else a top, or ball.

CHARLIE.

O, how I wish I had a pile
Of pennies, up so high!
(Measuring with his hand.)
What lots of playthings, pretty toys,
And candies I would buy!

JOHNNY.

And I would buy a big live horse,
And ride him all the day;
I'm sure I never should be tired,
Nor ever want to play.

CARRIE.

Now, boys, if you listen
I'll tell you something true:
I read about some boys and girls
About as big as you.

They live across the ocean,
Thousands of miles away;
They never read the Bible,
Nor ever learned to pray.

They never go to Sunday-school
[partially legible]

[pencil notation at right margin: "NCC 87-452" (partially legible)]
safety_reason: Racial oppression is implied and stereotyping is possibly present because the story uses the term "negro" for a servant in a context of suspicion and blame, reflecting historically racist language and roles. The final word(s) of the middle column and bottom of the right column are cut off, so these portions are marked as partially legible.

The poem presents two boys and a girl discussing how to spend pennies, shifting from toys and candy to Christian missionary concerns about children overseas who do not attend Sunday school or read the Bible.

full_desc:
The image shows a vertically oriented commemorative ribbon or badge honoring Pauli Murray, displayed against a plain medium-purple background. At the top is an ornate gold-colored horizontal bar with decorative scrollwork and an empty central slot, which appears to serve as the clasp or hanger for the ribbon. Suspended from this bar is a black satin-like fabric ribbon with white printed text and a central portrait framed in white. The bottom edge of the ribbon is finished with a fringe of fine black threads.

At the upper portion of the ribbon, in large, bold, all-capital white letters, is the name “PAULI MURRAY.” Directly below, in slightly smaller but still bold white capitals, are the dates “1910–1985.” Further down, below the dates, is a circular, black-and-white photographic portrait printed onto the ribbon. The portrait is set within a decorative white oval frame that has a scalloped outer edge and an inner border of small white circles, giving it a cameo-like appearance. Beneath the portrait, in bold white capital letters across several lines, is text noting an event from 1938: it states that Pauli Murray was denied admission to “segregated UNC-CH,” with the year “1938” and the phrase “DENIED ADMISSION TO SEGREGATED UNC-CH” separated by dashes. Below this is a thin horizontal white line with a small, stylized leaf-like motif at its center. Under the line, more white text appears in all capitals, consisting of a quotation. The quotation uses the historical term “Negro” and attributes determination specifically to women in the struggle; it is clearly legible and framed in quotation marks. The ribbon overall appears to be in good condition, with crisp printing and intact fringe, and it functions as a memorial or honorific artifact commemorating Pauli Murray’s life, their exclusion from a segregated university in 1938, and a documented statement about the role of women in the Black freedom struggle.

The visible printed text is clearly legible, uses a bold serif typeface, and is laid out in centered lines. The historical context suggested by the text is the Jim Crow era of legal segregation in the United States and the long Black freedom struggle, with explicit reference to racially segregated higher education and to women’s contributions to that struggle. The physical characteristics—satin-like black fabric, gold ornamental bar, white lettering, and fringed bottom—indicate a commemorative or ceremonial ribbon, possibly intended for display on clothing, at events, or as part of a memorial collection.

Misidentification risk is medium because Pauli Murray is identified by name and depicted in a portrait on the ribbon, and this linkage, while strongly supported by the printed text, should still be treated with some caution in archival identification.

full_desc:
The image shows three young adults in vintage-style clothing posing indoors between two large, ornate red curtains. The curtains frame the scene on both sides and are made of a heavy fabric with gold floral patterns and tasselled tiebacks. The floor is covered with a patterned red and gold carpet that matches the curtains. Bright light from a large window or doorway behind them creates a backlit effect, making their silhouettes and clothing stand out while the background details beyond the opening are mostly washed out in white and yellow tones.

In the center foreground, an individual with light to medium skin tone sits sideways on a tall stool, with bare feet resting on the carpet. They wear a long, fitted red dress with a repeating decorative pattern in yellow and black, and the dress extends down to the floor. Their dark hair is styled in two braids that hang over the front of their shoulders. Their hands rest lightly on their lap and on the edge of the stool, and their body faces slightly to the right relative to the camera.

Standing on the left is an adult with a light skin tone wearing clothing suggestive of early-to-mid 20th century workwear or costume. They wear a brownish-gray brimmed hat, a long-sleeved dark checkered shirt, and high-waisted dark trousers held up by light-colored suspenders. Their pants are loose and extend down to brown shoes. Their posture is relaxed, with arms hanging down at their sides.

On the right stands an adult with a medium-dark skin tone, also in vintage-inspired attire. They wear a light-colored cap, a light striped long-sleeved shirt, and a light gray vest over it. A loose, long tie in an orange or salmon color hangs down the front. Their trousers are knickerbocker-style, ending below the knee, and they wear bright turquoise socks with a diamond or argyle-like pattern, along with dark shoes. Their stance is casual, with one arm by their side. The overall setting and coordinated outfits suggest a staged or themed portrait, possibly taken in a studio or decorated interior location styled with rich red textiles and bright backlighting.
safety_reason: No elevated risks identified.

They wear a thick, knitted sweater with a black-and-white marled pattern and a light-colored, chunky knit scarf wrapped around their neck. A dark strap runs diagonally across their chest, supporting the banjo.

The banjo is prominently featured in the foreground, held horizontally across the person’s body. The round metal banjo body is visible at the lower left, with the person’s right hand positioned over the strings near the head, fingers curved as if picking. Their left hand is placed on the neck of the banjo, fingers pressing on the frets, suggesting they are forming a chord. The banjo neck is dark, with small white diamond-shaped fret markers and metal tuning pegs at the headstock; there appears to be a small brand or maker’s mark on the headstock, but it is too small to read clearly. The background is an outdoor wooded setting with the rough bark of a large tree trunk on the left and out-of-focus brown and tan leaves and branches suggesting late autumn. Overall, the photograph appears to be a candid or documentary-style portrait of Rhiannon playing a banjo in a forested area, with natural light and warm, muted earth tones dominating the scene.

full_desc:
The image is a rectangular digital promotional flyer for a webinar titled “Polynesian PipeLine Webinar.png,” using a teal, navy blue, black, and white color scheme with multiple logos, text blocks, and two portrait photographs. The layout is split primarily into a left section featuring images and the book cover, and a right section with event details and moderator information. A horizontal band of text runs across the top, and institutional logos line the bottom.

At the top center against a black background, green and white printed text announces the event. The top line in green reads “UNC APAHM Webinar.” Below that, in white, is a multi-line title: “Navigating Athletic Labor: American Football & the ‘Polynesian Pipeline’”. A final line in green beneath this reads “with Dr. Lisa Uperesa.”

Beneath this header, occupying much of the left and central area, is a tilted composite featuring a portrait photograph on the left and a book cover on the right, arranged like overlapping cards. The left image shows an adult wearing a black outer garment over a patterned green top, with long dark hair, seated in front of a blurred interior background with vertical window blinds. The right image is the cover of a book titled “Gridiron Capital.” The book cover is predominantly black and white, showing a close-up photograph of an American football held by a person’s arm. The main title text “Gridiron Capital” is printed in large letters, with “Gridiron” in green and “Capital” in white. Smaller text below, in white, reads “How American Football Became a Samoan Game Lisa Uperesa,” with the subtitle and author’s name in uppercase letters.

On the right half of the flyer, against a dark navy background, white text in a serif font lists the scheduling details. Near the upper-right quadrant, it reads: “Wednesday, April 26th 6pm” on three centered lines. Below this, closer to the lower-right corner, is a small, circular-framed portrait photograph set within a green ring, showing an adult in a dark top against a neutral background. To the left of this circular photo, white text reads: “Moderated by Dr. Zachary Yukio Kerr, EXSS” on multiple lines.

Along the bottom, a lighter blue horizontal band spans the width of the flyer. Centered in this band, dark blue text reads: “Registration: go.unc.edu/Polynesian”. Below the band, on a white strip at the very bottom, there are three institutional logos spaced from left to right. On the left is a University of North Carolina interlocking “NC” logo in light blue with the words “CAROLINA ATHLETICS” in blue uppercase letters. In the center is a vertical logo with a small UNC icon above the words “UNC ASIAN AMERICAN CENTER” in blue uppercase letters. On the right is another UNC interlocking “NC” logo, next to the words “CAMPUS RECREATION” in blue uppercase letters, and the tagline “STAY ACTIVE” in smaller blue uppercase text underneath.

In the upper-left corner, overlapping the dark background, there is a small circular emblem with a multicolored ring. Around the ring, printed text reads “Campus Life Experience” with the acronym “CLE” in the center in blue letters. The overall style of the flyer is clean and professional, clearly promoting a university-sponsored webinar dealing with American football, athletic labor, and the so-called “Polynesian Pipeline,” featuring Dr. Lisa Uperesa and moderated by Dr. Zachary Yukio Kerr.

A vertical black line separates this from the words “ASIAN AMERICAN CENTER” in all caps, also in black. Decorative purple swirl motifs appear in the upper left and upper right corners.

Centered beneath the logo line is large dark blue text reading “CELEBRATES PRIDE MONTH!” in all capital letters, spanning most of the width of the graphic. Below this text, in the central area of the image, there is a rectangular photograph of a wall-mounted display composed of several white poster sheets. Each poster features printed text, one or more small photos of individuals or artwork, and a visible black-and-white QR code. The posters are arranged in a grid-like layout against a light-colored wall with vertical panel lines. The posters highlight different individuals; their names are printed in large capital letters at the top of each sheet. From left to right, visible names include “VEENA AURORA” at upper left, “OSCAR YI HOU” at lower left, “BERNICE BING” centered at the top, “HANH THI PHAM” centered below, an “ANTONIUS–” name partially visible at the top right, and “EUGENE LEE YANG” at lower right. Each sheet includes smaller paragraphs of printed text that are too small to read clearly in this view, plus at least one color photograph next to or above the text blocks. There are QR codes in the lower or side sections of several posters. The entire central display photo is framed by a thin gradient border that shifts through warm colors such as pink, orange, and yellow.

Starting from the bottom edge of the central photo and extending toward the bottom of the overall graphic is a wide, stylized rainbow path that appears to recede into the distance. This path consists of broad diagonal bands of color—red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet—arranged side by side to evoke the Pride flag. The rainbow stripes are shown in perspective, wider at the bottom edge of the graphic and narrowing as they approach the center, giving a sense of depth and leading the viewer’s eye up toward the display photo and the “CELEBRATES PRIDE MONTH!” text. Overall, the graphic visually connects the UNC Asian American Center branding with LGBTQ+ Pride colors and highlights a curated exhibit featuring Asian and Asian American figures associated with Pride Month, presented in a clean, poster-based wall display.

The individual is centered in the frame and shown from about mid‑thigh upward. They have long, straight dark brown hair that falls past their chest on both sides. They wear a bright red blazer with the sleeves casually rolled up to reveal a lighter red or pink lining, over a black, knee‑length dress with a V‑shaped neckline and wrap‑style front. Long, narrow turquoise earrings hang down on either side of the neck. Their left hand rests on their hip, with fingers spread slightly, and a ring is visible on the ring finger. Their right arm hangs naturally by their side with another ring visible on that hand. 

The background shows a broad brick walkway composed of rectangular pavers in various shades of red, pink, and gray, forming subtle linear patterns. On the left, there is a light‑colored modern building with large windows and a metal railing near a raised platform or terrace. On the right, a red‑brick building runs along the walkway with a dark cylindrical trash or recycling receptacle visible in the distance. Further back, beyond the buildings, there are trees with green foliage, indicating a landscaped campus or urban setting. The lighting suggests daylight, with soft shadows indicating the image was likely taken outdoors in natural light. There is no visible text in the scene.

full_desc:
The image is a color illustration, likely an early modern print or engraving that has been hand-colored, depicting two Indigenous (Native American) adults standing on a grassy shoreline overlooking a broad river or coastal inlet. The scene is framed by a narrow black border, with a band of pale paper showing at the top and bottom, suggesting it is a page from a book or atlas. At the very bottom edge, faint handwritten or printed text is visible but is too small and indistinct to read clearly.

In the foreground stand two muscular, light-brown–skinned Indigenous adults, shown nearly full height. The person on the left faces the viewer with their body turned slightly to the right. They stand barefoot on uneven green ground with a few rocks and bare patches, legs apart in a firm stance. Their arms are folded across the chest. They wear a short, dark reddish-brown wrap or skirt made of cloth or possibly leather, hanging from the waist to mid-thigh, with a fringe along the bottom edge. Around the neck is a cord from which hangs a large, dark rectangular pendant plate resting on the upper chest. The person’s hair is light brown or blondish and tied back, with a topknot or loop at the back of the head. Their upper body is bare, showing defined shoulder, chest, and arm muscles.

The person on the right is positioned slightly farther back and turned away from the viewer, looking toward the water. This figure is also barefoot and muscular, with the back, shoulders, and arms prominently outlined. They wear a yellowish-brown draped garment wrapped around the waist and hips, extending to mid-thigh with a long fringe along the hem, similar in style to the left figure’s garment but in a different color. The cloth is gathered and overlaps at one hip, creating folds. Their upper body is bare, and the spine and back muscles are carefully delineated. The person’s hair is brown, gathered back and hanging to the neck. They appear to wear a circular earring in one visible ear. Both figures are nude from the waist up and from mid-thigh down, but the depiction is stylized and not sexualized.

The midground shows gently sloping green banks with patches of bare earth and low vegetation along the edge of a wide grey-blue body of water. On the left, the shoreline forms a small inlet or bay with irregular edges. Across the water in the distance, a low strip of land with green vegetation runs horizontally, suggesting the opposite bank or distant shore. In the water are multiple small boats or canoes with tiny, indistinct human figures paddling; the craft are elongated and low, consistent in style, and spread across the water, indicating activity such as travel or fishing. The surface of the water is lightly lined to indicate ripples.

The background consists of a wide, softly colored sky that transitions from a reddish or peach tone near the horizon, suggesting dawn or dusk, to pale yellow and then to light blue and deeper blue toward the top of the image. There are no distinct clouds, buildings, or mountains visible, only the horizontal bands of color. The overall style, including the figures’ poses, the hand-coloring, and the framing, suggests a historical ethnographic or travel illustration, possibly intended to depict a Native American elder or leader in a stylized, idealized manner. The print appears to be in good condition; colors are clear and vivid, line work is sharp, and there are no obvious tears or heavy stains visible within the frame.

Overall, the artifact appears to be a historical, hand-colored engraving or print from a book, portraying two Indigenous people in minimal clothing on a riverbank, with canoes and distant land across the water, likely intended as a visual representation of Native American leadership or status as suggested by the reference title.
safety_reason: The image depicts stylized representations of Indigenous (Native American) people from a historical print, which may reflect stereotypical or generalized portrayals common in early ethnographic or colonial-era illustrations, hence the 'POSSIBLY' for stereotyping. There is small printed or handwritten text at the bottom that is too small to read clearly in this reproduction, so legibility is marked as DIFFICULT.

Small canoes with tiny figures paddle across the wide river under a softly colored dawn or dusk sky.

The windows are covered with light-colored curtains that are tied back, allowing daylight to brighten the room. To the right side of the image, there is a set of additional windows with similar tied-back curtains. Near the center back wall, there is a shelving unit or entertainment stand holding an older-style CRT television and various small objects; a vase with red flowers sits on one shelf. A white side table appears toward the right, near the standing individual in the Planet Hollywood shirt. The overall impression is of a domestic interior, with the family grouped for an informal but intentional portrait.

The photograph appears to be a contemporary color digital image. The colors are warm and well-saturated, and the room is evenly lit, likely by natural light from the windows combined with interior lighting. No damage or aging is visible; the image looks clean and sharp, suitable for archival use documenting a Burmese family in a home environment.

full_desc:
The image shows a black-and-white historical photograph mounted on a black album page. The photograph is centered on the page with wide black margins around it. Below the photograph, there is a handwritten caption in white ink. The album page has two punched holes along the left edge, indicating it was part of a bound volume.

The photograph itself depicts a group of uniformed military figures walking along a wide, rough dirt road through a devastated landscape, suggestive of a war zone. There are at least five adults visible walking toward the camera in a loose line abreast. Based on clothing style and context, they appear to be white adults. All wear military uniforms of early 20th-century European style. The central figure is identified by the caption as President Poincaré. This individual wears a lighter-colored uniform tunic with a belt and decorations on the chest, along with boots and a military cap. To this person’s right, another person in a darker, more formal uniform coat with rows of medals or decorations on the chest and a peaked cap appears to be a senior officer or general. Other accompanying individuals wear lighter, simpler uniforms with puttees or gaiters and caps, suggestive of field officers or staff. Their postures are upright as they walk forward; their arms hang naturally or swing slightly at their sides.

The background on both sides of the road shows extensive destruction. On the left side, there are remnants of shattered structures, including what appears to be the skeletal remains of buildings or walls silhouetted against the sky. On the right side, there is a bare, broken tree and the ruins of additional structures or debris. The ground beside the road appears churned and uneven, with scattered rubble and possibly shell holes, reinforcing the impression of a battlefield or heavily shelled area. The sky is a pale, uniform gray, typical of overcast conditions in old photographs, with no distinct clouds visible.

The caption beneath the photograph is handwritten in a clear cursive style and is easily legible. It serves to identify the main subject and provides historical context by naming “President Poincaré” and indicating that the others are generals. Taken together, the physical format (mounted on a black album page with punched holes and handwritten caption), the uniforms, and the devastated landscape suggest that this is an early 20th-century wartime documentary photograph, likely produced as part of a photo album or official record documenting an inspection or visit to the front.

Physically, the artifact appears to be in good condition with no obvious tears or heavy staining visible in the reproduction. The black album page provides high contrast around the lighter-toned photograph. The overall style, monochrome palette, and handwritten caption indicate a formal, archival presentation intended to document the presence of a national leader and senior military officers in a war-damaged area.

The image is a color photograph of an outdoor excavation scene at the Warren Wilson archaeological site in Buncombe County, North Carolina. In the foreground, a young white adult sits on a hollow concrete cinder block at the edge of a rectangular excavation pit with straight, vertical walls and an exposed soil profile. The individual has straight, dark brown hair cut to about ear length and is bent forward over a small wooden folding table, concentrating on writing or drawing in a notebook or form. They wear a light-colored short-sleeve button-up shirt, light shorts with frayed hems, and light beige lace-up shoes without visible socks. Their posture is slightly hunched, with one forearm resting on the table and the other hand holding a pencil or pen.

The wooden folding table is positioned just inside the excavated area on the packed earth floor. On the tabletop are several items: an open binder or notebook with white pages, additional stacked papers or notebooks, a light-colored zippered bag (possibly canvas) lying to the right, and a folded white cloth or paper draped across part of the materials. A small rectangular object, possibly a tool or box, hangs at the front edge of the table. The soil surrounding the person is reddish-brown, with compacted surfaces and some small rocks visible, typical of an excavation unit. To the left, a sheet of plywood leans against the edge of the pit.

In the midground, just beyond the excavation square, there is a low mound or berm of excavated earth. A length of dark plastic sheeting or tarp is spread irregularly across the top of the mound, partially covering the soil. Behind this, the ground transitions into tall green grass and mixed vegetation, including some leafy plants close to the pit edge. Wooden posts and simple framing elements, possibly parts of site infrastructure or fencing, appear on the left and right edges of the image.

The background shows an open rural landscape with a slightly sloping grassy field leading toward a medium-sized rectangular building with a metal or light-colored roof and dark walls, situated near the center of the image. The building stands in front of a line of dense green trees that rise up into a wooded hillside. Above the trees, the sky appears overcast or hazy, suggesting cloudy weather. The photograph overall documents a person engaged in field recording or drawing at an archaeological excavation unit in a rural setting, with clear emphasis on the working conditions and surrounding landscape.

No clearly legible text is visible on any of the papers, notebooks, or equipment in the image. Any writing present is too small or distant to read.

University Day

Platform Party: Assembling in 105 South Building (rain location: Heavner Gallery)

Processional music begins

Platform Party is seated and Chancellor goes to the Podium

The image is a promotional graphic for a digitized newspaper collection. The overall background is a light, textured off‑white resembling crumpled paper. At the very top left, in small black type, is the date “February, 2023.” Centered near the top is the University of North Carolina branding: a small icon of the UNC Old Well followed by the letters “UNC” in a serif font, and to the right the words “ASIAN AMERICAN CENTER” in uppercase letters.

Below this, in large bold black capital letters spanning almost the full width, is the headline: “DIGITIZED EAST WIND NOW AVAILABLE.” Beneath that, in smaller type, is the line “Written by :  UNC Students.” The central portion of the graphic contains a grayscale reproduction of a page from a publication titled “East Wind.” Along the top edge of the reproduced page is a dark band with white text: on the left it reads “2 | EAST WIND” and on the right “SPRING 2005.” Below that is a large article headline, “Why read East Wind?” in bold letters. Under the headline is a column of printed article text in a serif font, describing Asian Americans being labeled a “model minority,” mentioning Asian Americans’ efforts and voices, and referring to East Wind’s role and its origins at UNC’s Asian Students Association; most of this body text is too small to read clearly. On the left side of the article is a rectangular grayscale portrait photograph framed by a thin border. On the right side of the reproduced page is a boxed sidebar titled “EAST WIND” listing roles and staff, including an Editor‑in‑Chief, an Assistant Editor, a Design Editor, and Contributing Writers; the role titles are legible while some of the smaller name text is harder to read.

Below the reproduced newspaper page, across the bottom of the graphic in large black serif text, is a promotional statement about the digitization project. It reads that “UNC’s Wilson Library has digitized the issues of East Wind from our collection!” followed by an invitation to browse the collection at a short web address, printed as “go.unc.edu/EastWindNewspaper.” The overall composition presents information in a clear, poster‑like layout combining institutional branding, a sample newspaper page, and access information for the digital collection.

full_desc:
The image is a color photograph of an illuminated manuscript miniature on a folio identified as Leiden, Bibliotheek der Rijksuniversiteit, Voss. L. F. 3, folio 41r. The miniature is framed within a red rectangular border set against the pale, slightly stained parchment of the page. Inside the frame, three white adults stand on a narrow red baseline in front of a patterned background. The background is olive green filled with a regular grid of geometric motifs: square or octagonal shapes outlined in a darker tone, each containing a smaller angular form, giving a tiled, decorative effect typical of medieval manuscript illumination.

On the left stands a figure in a long orange-red robe that reaches the ankles, with a narrow white border near the hem. The robe has a simple, slightly fitted cut, and the individual wears black shoes. They also wear an orange-red hat with a flat, wide top and a slightly extended brim, lined with white on the underside. The person faces to the right, toward the other two figures, and raises their right hand with the index finger extended upward in a gesture that suggests speaking or addressing the others; the left hand is slightly bent at the elbow. The facial profile shows a prominent nose and short, dark hair visible under the hat.

On the right side of the image, two additional white adults stand close together, facing the left figure. The central person wears a long, slightly translucent-looking brownish-orange outer garment reaching to the ankles, with a pale edge at the hem and a visible darker under-layer at the lower part. They wear black shoes and a dark hood or head covering that drapes down around the shoulders. Their arms are bent; one hand is held near the chest, while the other is in contact with the right-hand figure’s hands.

The rightmost person wears a long, dark blue robe with fine white linear accents along the collar, shoulders, sleeves, and hem, also reaching the ankles, and dark shoes. They wear a broad, flat hat similar in shape to the left figure’s but colored in a brown or orange-brown tone with a lighter underside. This person faces the central figure and extends both hands to hold or support the central figure’s arm or hands, suggesting a formal interaction or presentation. All three figures are shown in a stylized, flat medieval style with elongated bodies, minimal modeling, and simple contour lines typical of Gothic manuscript art.

The miniature sits within the larger manuscript page. At the far right edge of the image, part of a vertical column of black Gothic script is visible on the parchment, with a few letters of one or two lines discernible but not fully shown. Below the miniature, the parchment shows a faint, reddish-brown mark or flourish that may be part of a later annotation or decoration. Along the right margin, there is also the edge of another decorative panel bordered in black and orange with a small geometric pattern, likely part of the page’s overall layout. The folio shows some age-related discoloration and small spots, but the painted colors—especially the orange-red, dark blue, and green—remain vivid, with some wear and minor abrasions visible in the central orange-brown garment and background.

Overall, this appears to be a medieval manuscript illumination, probably illustrating a narrative or legal/religious scene, with three figures interacting in a formal, frontal composition on a patterned ground. The physical characteristics indicate tempera or similar pigments on parchment with a clearly defined painted frame integrated into a larger column of text.

full_desc:
The image is a color photograph of a page from an illuminated medieval manuscript, identified in the reference information as “Montpellier, Ecole de Médecine 89, folio 10r.” The page is oriented vertically with rounded corners visible in the photo, suggesting it is part of a bound codex. The parchment background is a light beige with some darker speckling and age toning.

Near the top half of the page there is a rectangular miniature painting framed by a narrow light-colored border. Inside the miniature, against a dark green or black background, two standing human figures in long garments are depicted flanking a central object. The figure on the left wears an ankle‑length, orange or reddish tunic with long sleeves, and dark leggings and shoes. Their head is covered with a rounded cap in a similar orange tone, with hair or a band visible at the edges. Their left arm is bent upward near the chest, and their right arm extends forward and downward toward the central object. The figure on the right wears a long, greenish-brown tunic or robe reaching below the knees, with a darker collar and cuffs, and similarly dark leggings and shoes. This person is bent forward at the waist, leaning over the central object with their head inclined toward it. Both figures have pale, stylized faces characteristic of medieval manuscript illustration, with simple outlines for noses and eyes and short, light-colored hair.

Between the two figures is a tall, narrow, upright pale form that may represent a column, instrument, or anatomical element; it rises from a rounded base. This base is depicted as a domed shape with a green top and a band of orange with small arc-like forms around its lower edge, resting on the ground line. The right-hand figure appears to be touching or holding the upright form with both hands. The left-hand figure gestures toward it. The scene is set against a flat, dark background without additional landscape or architectural details.

Above and below the miniature, the manuscript contains multiple lines of Latin text written in a dense, brown ink in a Gothic script. The lines are tightly spaced. Above the miniature, a few lines of text are visible at the top edge of the page; below the miniature, a larger block of text occupies the remaining lower half of the folio. The handwriting is angular and compact, with characteristic Gothic letterforms. Most of the text is difficult to read clearly at this resolution, but it is consistently written in a formal book hand. In the lower text block, an enlarged decorative initial “A” in the left margin is drawn in red or orange ink with additional pen‑flourishing and simple border lines extending into the margin. Throughout the text block, some capital letters or paragraph marks in red or orange ink stand out among the darker main text, providing visual emphasis and likely indicating section starts.

Overall, the artifact appears to be a medical or scholarly manuscript page from the medieval period, on parchment, with an illustrative miniature integrated into the text column. The page shows typical signs of age such as slight discoloration and minor surface speckling but appears generally well preserved, with text and image both clearly visible. The miniature’s simple composition, flat colors, and stylized figures are consistent with medieval European manuscript illumination, and the central scene likely illustrates a medical or instructional episode related to the surrounding Latin text.

full_desc:
The image shows a rectangular piece of aged, cream-colored paper with handwritten text in dark ink across the upper half and center, and additional lighter pencil writing near the bottom. The paper has a horizontal crease running across the middle and slightly uneven, worn edges, indicating age or handling. There are small brownish spots and faint stains scattered over the surface.

Across the top portion, a line of cursive handwriting in dark ink runs from the left toward the right side. The writing is in flowing 19th‑century-style cursive and is clearly legible, though some letters have old-fashioned forms and the spelling reflects historical usage. Below this first line, another line of ink handwriting continues roughly centered horizontally, completing the short statement. Together they read as a continuous sentence about the writers’ place of birth and its distance from “Bankok,” described as the capital of “Siam.”

In the middle lower area of the page, below the crease, there are two prominent ink signatures written in large, decorative cursive. One signature, “Chang,” appears slightly left of center. To its right, spaced apart but on a similar horizontal level, is the second signature, “Eng.” Both signatures are written with thicker, more emphatic strokes than the text above, helping them stand out as names. Beneath these signatures, toward the lower center-right, there is a lighter pencil notation in a different hand, written in a more modern, less ornate cursive style. This annotation, in gray pencil, reads “The Siamese Twins,” explicitly identifying the signers using a historical term. The overall artifact appears to be a brief handwritten statement with signatures by the twin brothers Chang and Eng, preserved as a historical document, with later pencil annotation added for clarification.

The paper itself is plain with no printed lines, watermarks, or illustrations visible. The ink text is dark brown or black, suggesting iron gall ink that has aged. The document is in fair condition: the text is fully legible, but the sheet shows creasing, slight discoloration, and minor spots typical of older manuscripts. There are no decorative borders or additional marks beyond the handwriting and incidental stains.

full_desc:
The image is a black-and-white lithographic print showing a pair of conjoined adult Asian individuals standing indoors in formal dress, joined at the lower chest/upper abdomen. They stand on a patterned floor in a sparsely furnished, elegant interior. A heavy curtain with visible folds and a tassel hangs behind them on the left side of the image, suggesting a parlor or drawing-room setting. To the far right is a simple wooden side chair with an upholstered seat, with its front legs visible and rear portion cut off by the frame. On the far left, next to the curtain, there is a small table with curved, carved legs and a fringed cloth hanging down the side. On top of this table is a chessboard with chess pieces arranged on it.

The two conjoined individuals stand close together, with one on the viewer’s left and the other on the right, their bodies touching at the torso where a visible band of shared tissue links them at the abdomen. Both are dressed nearly identically in early–19th-century style formal attire: dark fitted tailcoats with broad lapels, waistcoats, high-collared shirts, and neckcloths or cravats. Their trousers are slim and straight, and they wear low shoes. Their hair is dark and cut relatively short. Each individual has one arm positioned behind the other’s back, suggesting a mutual embrace or support, and the individual on the viewer’s left holds a small booklet or pamphlet in their free hand; the cover of this booklet includes a small vignette illustration. A pair of gloves or possibly a folded cloth appears tucked into the coat pocket of the person on the left. The lighting and shading are rendered with fine lines typical of lithography, with careful detailing of the fabric folds and the pattern of the carpet.

Below the image, in the lower margin, there is printed and handwritten text providing publication information and a title. The central handwritten-style title reads “Eng-Chang.” Additional smaller printed text beneath the image states that the print was entered according to an act of Congress in a specified year by a named individual in the clerk’s office for the Southern District of New York, indicating a 19th-century American copyright notice. At the bottom left is a printer or lithographer credit, and at the bottom right there is an address line giving a street and city in New York. At the very top edge of the sheet, slightly right of center, a small penciled or printed catalog number is visible. The print appears well preserved, with clean paper, even margins, and no obvious tears or significant stains visible within the frame of the image.

Overall, this appears to be a formal, promotional or commemorative 19th-century lithograph of conjoined twins, identified in the title text as “Eng-Chang,” presented standing in a refined interior with props such as a chess table and chair to convey a genteel setting. The style, dress, and detailed caption information suggest it was produced as a commercial or documentary print for public viewing or sale.

full_desc:
Color photograph of an indoor event showing a group of adults gathered around a person standing at a microphone. The scene appears to be in a public or office-type building with gray walls and a drop ceiling with rectangular fluorescent light panels visible in the background. The right side of the image is dominated by the torso of a tall adult with dark-brown skin wearing a light gray, double-breasted suit jacket, a white dress shirt, and a patterned tie. In front of them is a metal microphone on a black stand positioned at chest height, suggesting the person is addressing the group or preparing to speak. A blue folder or portfolio is tucked under their left arm.

To the left, several adults are gathered close together facing toward the person at the microphone. The group appears to include white and Black adults of varying ages, from younger adults to older adults. Many are in mid-clap, with hands raised and palms together, suggesting applause. Clothing is business or casual-professional: a person in the foreground at left wears a dark suit jacket, light blue shirt, and patterned tie and holds a few sheets of white paper; another wears a bright orange shirt; another near the center wears a light-colored blouse with a floral pattern and dark pants; further back someone wears a plaid shirt, and another wears a light blue denim outfit. Hair styles and colors vary, including gray, short dark hair, and curly light brown or red hair. The background is filled with more people standing close together, creating the impression of a small crowd in a confined indoor space. Wooden paneling is visible behind the speaker on the right, framing part of the scene. The image appears to be a documentary or news-style photograph capturing a public address or announcement, possibly at a workplace, institutional lobby, or conference venue. There is no prominent visible signage or printed text in the environment that would further identify the event.

The photograph is in color and reasonably sharp, with even indoor lighting and no obvious physical damage such as tears or stains. The composition places the speaker at the microphone on the right edge and the applauding audience on the left and center, emphasizing the interaction between the crowd and the person addressing them. No brand logos or distinctive symbols are clearly visible on clothing or walls. Overall, this appears to be an event or press-style photo documenting an individual speaking to or being recognized by a diverse group of adults in an institutional setting.

full_desc:
The image shows a large outdoor commencement ceremony packed with graduating students wearing matching light blue academic gowns and mortarboard caps. The students fill stadium-style bleachers that rise in tiers from the bottom to the top of the frame, creating a dense field of blue. Nearly all of them are standing, many with one arm raised and fists in the air, suggesting a coordinated gesture or cheer. The mortarboards are mostly plain light blue, though a few appear to have decorations or slightly different colors on top. The gowns are ankle-length with wide sleeves, and some individuals wear stoles or honor cords in white or other light colors over their gowns. A few people in the crowd are not wearing caps, making their hair visible among the blue caps. The bleachers are light gray metal and visible in horizontal rows between groups of standing graduates.

In the lower foreground, slightly out of focus, are additional people wearing dark academic regalia, including black gowns and traditional caps with colored hoods or stoles, likely faculty or officials. Their darker clothing contrasts with the light blue of the main group. The overall color palette is dominated by the bright, uniform blue of the graduates’ attire against the neutral grays of the seating and the darker tones of the foreground gowns. The setting appears to be a large stadium or arena, with no visible stage or building features in this cropped view. No printed or handwritten text, signage, or banners are visible anywhere in the image.

The photograph appears to be a contemporary color image documenting a mass university or high school commencement ceremony. It is in good condition, with sharp focus on the central crowd, natural lighting, and vivid colors. There are no visible logos, flags, or other recognizable institutional symbols, aside from the generic academic gowns and caps which suggest a formal graduation context. The image’s significance lies in its depiction of a large cohort of graduates, unified by matching regalia and collective gestures, captured from a vantage point that emphasizes the scale of the gathering.
